awd_titl_txt: RUI: Catalyst Systems to Effect Asymmetric Induction in the Hydroamination of Olefins
awd_abstract_narration:
The Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division supports the research project by Professor Wenzel. Professor Wenzel is a faculty member at the W. M. Keck Science Department at Claremont McKenna College. She is developing new molecules to catalyze selective hydroamination of alkenes. Hydroamination reactions are an efficient route for the preparation of amines, a common structure found in pharmaceutical and agrichemical products. The reactions are focused on making the synthesis sustainable.   The catalyst molecules are designed to be readily available and to support robust reactions. The study is uncovering a wealth of fundamental information regarding the factors governing reaction design. The research is conducted entirely by undergraduate students. Professor Wenzel's program is well-poised to address the ongoing deficiency of underrepresented groups in science.  She has an excellent record in training underrepresented minority students and successfully encouraging them to pursue graduate studies in chemistry.  

This research outlines the preparation of chiral heterodonor phosphorous/thioether (P/S) and phosphorous/amine (P/N) ligands as alternatives to classically-used bisphosphines for coordination onto palladium, ruthenium, and copper. The chiral, bidentate ligands are equipped with strong and weak donor-heteroatom pairs (e.g., P/S or P/N) to utilize favorable electronics to strongly influence the stability and reactivity associated with stereochemistry-defining reaction intermediates. The new catalysts are evaluated in two types of hydroamination reactions: an intermolecular, asymmetric anti-Markovnikov hydroamination of unactivated olefins and the enantioselective, Markovnikov hydroamination of dienes to produce dihydroquinolines. It is through a robust program in the training of undergraduate researchers that Professor Wenzel tries to advance of science as well as the education of future science professionals.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division supported the project by Professor Wenzel, who is a faculty member at the W. M. Keck Science Department at Claremont McKenna College. The PI has developed transition-metal complexes to effect the hydroamination of alkenes. Hydroamination reactions involve the formal addition of a nitrogen-hydrogen bond across a carbon-carbon multiple bond, which can serve as an efficient route towards the preparation of chiral amines, a ubiquitous structural motif found in pharmaceutical and agrichemical products. The complete atom economy of this reaction satisfies several of the main tenets of sustainable, “green” chemistry. Reports from the Basic Energy Sciences Advisory Committee cite the hydroamination of olefins as one of the top ten catalysis targets for the 21st century. Research conducted during the term of the grant discovered a copper-based system for the anti-Markovnikov hydroamination of C=C, a particularly sought after regioselectivity of reaction. Yields as high as 90% were obtained. Efforts to translate this system to convey enantioselectivity are ongoing.

 

Two reactions were serendipitously discovered in conjunction with this research. In the first, it was found that a common reaction solvent, 1,4-dioxane, could serve as a competent carbon source for the N-formylation of amines. N-formyl amines serve as versatile building blocks in organic and bimolecular synthesis. The developed method does not require the use of stoichiometric activating reagents, and avoids the use of toxic gases, such as CO, or explosive reagents as the carbon source. The results of this research were reported in an article published in the Journal of Organic Chemistry (2020).  In the second reaction, hydroamination catalyst systems were re-deployed to catalyze the Friedel–Crafts-like benzylation of un-activated benzylic alcohols to form 1,1-diarylalkanes. This operationally convenient method employs readily available starting materials, is highly reproducible, and is tolerant of moisture. Excellent yields under mild conditions were obtained. The results of this research were reported as a high-impact article in the European Journal of Organic Chemistry (2019). Eleven undergraduate students were listed as coauthors in the peer-reviewed publications. Research during the funding period was additionally disseminated to the chemical community via 61 research lectures and poster presentations at American Chemical Society meetings and various undergraduate chemical research conferences.

 

Beyond the utility of the investigated systems, a principal broader impact of the PIs program is to effectively employ mentorship to prevent post-baccalaureate attrition from the sciences. It is through a robust program in the training of undergraduate researchers that Professor Wenzel endeavors to fulfill the NSF strategic plan in the advancement of science and the education of future STEM professionals. Throughout the funding period of CAT NSF 1566124, the PI employed inquiry-based learning strategies to complement undergraduate education in the classroom. Funding was used to formally train 26 students in the PI’s laboratory. Of these, 89% were from traditionally underrepresented groups. Of the 23 students who have completed their degrees, to date, 8 have gone to pursue doctoral studies in science (Harvard, Stanford, Scripps Research Institute, Caltech, Columbia University, UCLA, UC Davis). Ten have gone on to pursue medical degrees, and an additional two are currently working as technicians in scientific research labs. Training in the PI’s lab contributed to three undergraduate research Fulbrights. Of note, grant funds were used to implement accommodations to enable two students with manual disabilities to participate within the research program, which ultimately served as a springboard to enable them to go on to pursue doctoral studies in chemistry and medical school, respectively.


Last Modified: 09/06/2021
Modified by: Anna G Wenzel
